Under copper limitation, type II methanotrophs, the type X methanotroph, Methylococcus capsulatus Bath, and some type I methanotrophs can produce soluble methane monooxygenase (sMMO) rather than the usual copper-containing particulate type (pMMO) (Hanson and Hanson, 1996; Koh et al., 1993).

For this reason, methanotrophicbioreactors with high sMMO activities were developed to treat contaminated groundwater (Aziz et al., 1995; Phelps et al., 1990; Pressman et al., 1999), to produce sMMO-containing methanotrophs for bioaugmentation of contaminated sites (Duba et al., 1996; Rockne et al., 1998; Shah et al., 1996) or for industrial biotransformations (Lee et al., 1996).

source_span.text_evidence: Soluble methane monooxygenase (sMMO) can degrade many chlorinated and aromatic pollutants. It is produced by certain methanotrophs such as Methylosinus trichosporium when grown on methane under copper limitation but, due to its low aqueous solubility, methane cannot support dense biomass growth. In this study, when the growth-limiting substrate was switched from methane to methanol, in the presence of the particulate MMO inhibitor, allylthiourea, growth of M. trichosporium OB3b continued unabated and sMMO activity was completely retained. While a biomass density of only 2 g l -1 could be obtained on methane, 7.4 g l -1 was achieved by feeding methanol exponentially, and 29gl -1 was obtained using a modified feeding strategy employing on-line carbon dioxide production measurement. The aforementioned limitations in bioreactor productivity were at least partly due to the low aqueous solubility of methane. As a carbon source, methane is first oxidized to methanol by MMO. Many methanotrophs are able to grow on methanol, with no need for methane. Methanol is inexpensive and presents fewer safety concerns than methane.

source_span.text_evidence: Erlenmeyerflasks(250ml)containing50mlmediumwereautoclaved. The flasks were covered with foam stoppers and incubated at 30 ◦ C and 200rpm on a gyro-rotary shaker (Innova 44, New Brunswick Scientific, USA). For methane-grown innocula, the flasks were sealed with rubber stoppers fitted with two 0.2 𝛍 M filters. After inoculation, a methane/air mixture (20% CH4, v/v) was introduced to the flasks through the filter for 5 min at a flow rate of 3 l min -1 and then incubated at 30 ◦ C and 200rpm. When growth was observed, this culture was transferred to 2-l Erlenmeyer flasks containing 200ml NMS medium to prepare inocula for reactor fermentations.

source_span.text_evidence: Cell cultures were centrifuged and resuspended in NMS medium to a biomass concentration of 0.5gl -1 . Concentrated potassium formate was added to a final concentration of 20mM. The cell suspensions were incubated with naphthalene crystals at 200rpm, and 30 ◦ C for 1 h. The reaction solutions were then centrifuged and the naphthol content was determined by adding 0.1ml freshly prepared 1% o -dianisidine tetrazotized dye (Sigma-Aldrich) to 1 ml supernatant at the appropriate dilution. The absorbance at 530nm was measured immediately and related to a standard curve (0-7mgnaphtholl -1 ). Specific sMMO activity was calculated as naphthalene oxidation rate per gram of biomass.

source_span.text_evidence: The culture was initially grown in batch mode on NMS medium with methane as the sole source of carbon and energy. Headspace methane was maintained at 22% (v/v). As steady state was approached (judged by methane uptake rate, CO2 production, biomass concentration, and sMMO activity), sMMO activity of about 550 𝛍 mol naphthol produced gbiomass -1 h -1 was obtained (Fig. 1), which is comparable to the sMMO activity usually reported for this strain when grown on methane in the absence of copper (Bowman and Sayler, 1994; Koh et al., 1993). After stopping the methane supply and switching to feed containing methanol, the majority of the sMMOactivity remained intact. During the brief period when both methane and methanol were present, higher sMMO activity was observed.

The capacity of M. trichosporium OB3b to retain sMMO activity while growing on methanol was investigated. As steady state was approached (judged by methane uptake rate, CO2 production, biomass concentration, and sMMO activity), sMMO activity of about 550 𝛍 mol naphthol produced gbiomass -1 h -1 was obtained (Fig. 1), which is comparable to the sMMO activity usually reported for this strain when grown on methane in the absence of copper (Bowman and Sayler, 1994; Koh et al., 1993). During the brief period when both methane and methanol were present, higher sMMO activity was observed. The specific sMMO activity dropped only slightly to 490 𝛍 mol naphthol produced gbiomass -1 This level of sMMO activity was maintained for 24 generations. Much higher cell densities should be obtainable if the methanol concentration can be more rigorously controlled.

Therefore, we chose to examine sMMO production in a wild type strain growing on a more suitable growth substrate than methane. In our chemostat experiments, there was no apparent difference in sMMO production whether M. trichosporium OB3b was grown on methane or on methanol. Activity could be recovered by growing it on methane withcopperlimitation. We obtained a M. trichosporium OB3b biomass concentration of 29gl -1 using a CCPbased strategy to control the methanol concentration. This is similar to growth on methane.
